title: A 100-degree heat wave in Gaza offers a sweltering glimpse of a tough summer to come
summary: In the Gaza Strips Rafah, displaced Palestinian families are enduring extreme heat in tents unsuitable for the summer months. With temperatures reaching 100 degrees Fahrenheit, the tents have become unbearable, causing health issues and discomfort. Aid workers express concerns about infectious diseases spreading in the heat and the shortage of basic necessities like air conditioning and drinking water. One Palestinian woman died due to heat exhaustion, while medical personnel at field hospitals struggle to treat children suffering from heat-related eye irritation. Despite the extreme conditions, thousands of Palestinians have sought relief in the Mediterranean Sea. Aid organizations are considering adjusting work hours to avoid peak heat and are exploring options to provide shade and respite from the relentless summer ahead.

title: A student club is suing its school, saying its pro-Palestinian views were censored
summary: Students at Jackson-Reed High School in Washington, D.C., have filed a lawsuit against their principal and school district, alleging censorship of their pro-Palestinian speech. The school allegedly prevented the Arab Student Union from distributing materials, holding a Palestinian Culture Night, and screening a documentary critical of Israel. The lawsuit cites the Vietnam War-era case Tinker v. Des Moines, which established students First Amendment rights in schools. The students argue that their freedom of speech was violated, as the schools actions were motivated by a desire to suppress their viewpoint on the ongoing war in Gaza. The school administration has not yet responded to the lawsuit, and the students are seeking a federal judge to intervene before the end of the school year.

title: An illegal migrant, age 17, drowned in a Bosnian river. Here's how citizens responded
summary:
17-year-old Ajmal Khan died while crossing the Drina River in Bosnia-Herzegovina, part of a common migration route towards wealthy European nations.

In Bosnia, dozens of migrants have drowned in the Drina attempting to reach other countries, and their families often struggle to find closure due to lack of information.

Volunteers like Nihad Suljić and Dr. Vidak Simić assist by providing support to families, arranging burials for unidentified bodies, and collecting DNA samples for potential identification.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) offers resources for families to locate missing migrants through the "Trace the Face" virtual photo gallery.

Despite the efforts of volunteers and organizations, many migrant families remain unaware of their loved ones fate and face obstacles in bringing bodies home for burial.

Approximately 29,000 migrants lost their lives along migration routes to Europe between 2014 and 2021, with an additional 5,684 deaths since 2021.

title: Got brothers or sisters? Warm sibling bonds help booster happiness as you age
summary: Research indicates that sibling relationships can significantly impact emotional health in later life. A study found that individuals with close bonds with siblings in early adulthood experienced less anxiety and depression at midlife. The benefits of these relationships extend into retirement, with warm sibling connections being associated with reduced loneliness and better emotional well-being. Sibling relationships undergo a shift around age 23, becoming more stable and less conflictual. Despite occasional disagreements, it is important to nurture sibling relationships through open communication, understanding perspectives, and establishing clear lines of communication, especially when caring for aging parents.

title: What abortion politics has to do with new rights for pregnant workers
summary: Republican-led states have filed a lawsuit against the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) over an "abortion accommodation mandate" in the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act (PWFA). The PWFA, passed in 2022, requires employers to accommodate employees who are pregnant or postpartum, including providing time off for doctors appointments. The EEOCs implementing regulation includes "abortion" as a related medical condition that employers must accommodate. This has led to opposition from anti-abortion groups and certain lawmakers, who argue that the mandate supports abortion rights. The lawsuit, filed in federal court, seeks to halt the effective date of the regulation and vacate the "abortion-accommodation mandate." Womens advocates, however, view the lawsuit as an attempt to undermine protections for pregnant workers and womens health. The PWFA received bipartisan support during its passage, and the EEOC has already received complaints alleging violations of the law.

title: Iran women's protests are the focus of 'Persepolis' author Marjane Satrapi's new book
summary: Marjane Satrapi, the renowned graphic novelist, has released her latest book, "Woman, Life, Freedom." Inspired by the Iranian protests sparked by Mahsa Aminis death, the book collaborates with various artists and intellectuals to depict the uprising and its historical context. Satrapi emphasizes the significance of the protests, particularly the role of young women and the support from young men, as a pushback against the patriarchal culture underpinning Irans regime. The book includes diverse perspectives, such as illustrations by Patricia Bolaños depicting the "noble-born" elite and their disconnect from the struggles of ordinary Iranians. With translations available in English, Persian, and French, Satrapi aims to raise global awareness of the Iranian peoples fight for change. While acknowledging the diasporas support, she stresses that true transformation must come from within Iran.

title: Mike Johnson and the troubled history of recent Republican speakers
summary: Speaker Mike Johnson is likely to continue in his role despite a threat by Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene to remove him. Greene has not yet "privileged" her motion to oust Johnson, which would necessitate a vote within two days. Several Democrats have indicated they would support Johnson in a vote, preventing Greene from gaining enough votes to remove him. Johnsons recent bipartisan support for aid to Ukraine, Israel, and Taiwan has boosted his stature and earned him praise from both parties. However, Greenes motion serves as a warning that Johnsons position is tenuous, as Republican speakers have historically faced challenges and short tenures. The current state of Republican politics is highly unstable, and Johnsons tenure echoes the tumultuous history of Republican speakers since World War II, with only one voluntarily leaving office since the 1920s.

title: South Africa remembers an historic election every April 27, Freedom Day
summary:
On April 27, 1994, South Africans celebrated their first all-race democratic election, ending decades of apartheid oppression. The African National Congress (ANC) won overwhelmingly, with Nelson Mandela becoming the countrys first Black president. This monumental vote marked the beginning of a new era, as millions of Black South Africans exercised their right to vote for the first time.

Three decades later, South Africas "Freedom Day" is still celebrated, commemorating the pivotal election that brought about racial equality. However, the country faces significant socio-economic challenges, including widespread poverty and unemployment. The ANC, which has been in power since 1994, is facing criticism for not improving the lives of many South Africans.

The 30th anniversary of the 1994 election coincides with another potentially transformative event: the upcoming general election on May 29. While the ANC is predicted to remain the largest party, it may lose its parliamentary majority. This could lead to new political alliances and a shift in South Africas political landscape.

title: Tornadoes collapse buildings and level homes in Nebraska and Iowa
summary: Tornadoes devastated the Midwest on Friday, wreaking havoc in Nebraska and Iowa. In Omaha, Nebraska, 40-50 homes were destroyed, while over 100 sustained damage, primarily in the Elkhorn area. In Lancaster County, three injuries occurred when a tornado collapsed an industrial building with 70 people inside. The National Weather Service issued tornado watches across several states for Saturday, with further storms anticipated. As of Friday night, no fatalities were reported, but two minor injuries were reported in Omaha. Despite warnings, the tornado struck during school dismissal, prompting schools to shelter students in place. Emergency crews are conducting thorough searches for victims and securing unsafe structures.

title: UAW strike at Daimler Truck averted at 11th hour
summary: The United Auto Workers (UAW) has secured a new contract for 7,300 Daimler Truck workers in North Carolina, preventing a potential strike. Under the agreement, workers will receive raises of at least 25% over four years, along with cost of living allowances and profit sharing, which are firsts for Daimler Truck workers. The unionized employees primarily work at plants producing Freightliner and Western Star trucks and Thomas Built buses. These gains mirror those obtained by Big 3 autoworkers last fall. The unions victory follows a recent success at Volkswagens Chattanooga, Tennessee plant and may motivate further organizing efforts at other foreign-owned auto plants in the South.

title: Midwest tornadoes cause severe damage in Omaha suburbs
summary: A tornado tore through suburban Omaha, Nebraska on Friday, damaging hundreds of homes and structures. Injuries were reported, but no fatalities have been confirmed. The tornado leveled homes and ripped roofs off in the Elkhorn area, leaving dozens of newly built homes severely damaged. Emergency crews are conducting door-to-door searches for potential victims trapped in debris. The tornado also caused damage at Eppley Airfield and crossed into Iowa, with injuries reported in Lancaster County before the Omaha strike. The Omaha Public Power District reported nearly 10,000 customers without power, and tornado watches were issued in neighboring states.

title: Biden administration abandons plan to ban menthol cigarettes, citing 'feedback'
summary: The Biden administration has indefinitely postponed the implementation of a ban on menthol tobacco products, citing controversy within the Black community as a key factor. Health and Human Services Secretary Xavier Becerra noted significant feedback from civil rights and criminal justice organizations. The ban, proposed over two years ago, faced backlash from anti-smoking advocates who argued that its postponement prioritizes politics over public health. Menthol cigarettes, which make up a significant portion of US tobacco sales, are disproportionately marketed to Black communities, women, and LGBTQ populations. Despite the known health risks, particularly the high lung cancer rates among Black smokers, the issue of menthol cigarette bans has divided the Black community, with some civil rights leaders advocating against a ban due to concerns about increased over-policing.

title: In Columbia University's protests of 1968 and 2024, what's similar — and different
summary: Last week, pro-Palestinian students occupied Columbia Universitys South Lawn, mirroring protests from 1968 motivated by the Vietnam War and the universitys military connections. The current protest is part of a wider movement against the Israel-Gaza conflict. However, there are distinctions. The 1968 protests also addressed the Harlem gym issue and included concerns of the Society of Afro-American Students. While police intervention in 1968 resulted in violence, the recent removal of demonstrators was peaceful. Notably, Black students in 1968 asked white students to leave a building due to differences in approach, foreshadowing later divisions among the protesters, including discontent among women regarding their lack of power. Despite the ongoing Israeli-Palestinian conflict, the 1968 protests achieved some success, leading to university policy changes related to research, construction, and military presence.

title: DRC is seeing its worst mpox outbreak — but has no vaccines or treatments yet. Why?
summary: The Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) currently lacks mpox vaccines and treatments amid an ongoing outbreak that has reported over 4,500 cases and 311 deaths this year. The DRC intends to use mpox vaccines but still needs vaccine approval and a delivery strategy. The CDC and WHO have assisted the DRC in expanding testing capacity and understanding the outbreak. The mpox strain circulating in the DRC (Clade I) is deadlier than the strain involved in the 2022 global outbreak, with a 10% fatality rate. There is insufficient data on vaccine efficacy among children and populations with underlying health conditions, and logistical challenges exist due to remote case locations and violent unrest. Despite declaring the outbreak a public health emergency, the DRC has not yet officially announced a health emergency, which would facilitate access to international support and resources.

title: Net neutrality is back: U.S. promises fast, safe and reliable internet for all
summary: On Thursday, the Federal Communications Commission voted to restore net neutrality regulations, classifying broadband as a public utility. This move aims to prevent internet service providers from restricting bandwidth, ensuring faster, safer, and more reliable internet connections for consumers. The rules, first introduced in 2015 and repealed under President Trump, prohibit internet service providers from favoring or blocking certain content. The decision is expected to face legal challenges from the telecommunications industry, but will go into effect 60 days after its publication in the Federal Register. Despite concerns from Republican commissioners and the industry about government overreach and the potential for decreased innovation, supporters of net neutrality argue that it ensures equal access to the internet and protects consumer data.

title: King Charles III is returning to royal duties after his cancer diagnosis
summary: Buckingham Palace has announced King Charles IIIs imminent return to public duties after undergoing cancer treatment and recovery. The King and Queen Camilla will visit a cancer center next week, marking his return. The Palace did not disclose the type or stage of Charles cancer, which was initially diagnosed in early February. Charles reign began with the passing of Queen Elizabeth II in September 2022. His coronation took place in May 2023. The Palace expressed gratitude for the support received during a year marked by challenges and celebrations, with the anniversary of Charles coronation approaching. The King and Queen will also host the Emperor and Empress of Japan for a state visit in June.

title: A baby girl born orphaned and premature after an Israeli airstrike in Gaza has died
summary: In Rafah, Gaza, an airstrike killed a pregnant mother, Sabreen al-Sakani, her husband, and toddler daughter. However, medics successfully performed an emergency cesarean section to deliver her baby girl, who was named Sabreen after her mother. Despite the efforts of medical staff at the Emirati hospital, the premature infant passed away five days later at the age of five. The babys uncle expressed his willingness to care for her, but she was buried alongside her father. The incident occurred amidst an increase in Israeli airstrikes on Rafah, where Hamas battalions are said to operate. The Israeli military has not responded to inquiries about why the Jouda familys home was targeted.

title: A Delta Air Lines flight makes an emergency return following concerns with plane wing
summary: Delta Air Lines Flight 520, a Boeing 767-300 departing from JFK Airport to Los Angeles, was forced to return to JFK on Friday morning due to an emergency flight deck indication related to the right wing emergency exit slide and a sound near the right wing. The aircraft circled the tristate area before landing safely at JFK. No pressurization issues were reported. The 34-year-old aircraft, which was delivered to Delta in 1990, has been removed from service for thorough evaluation. The FAA will investigate the incident. A passenger reported a loud sound and feeling "overwhelmed" and "scared" during the incident.

title: Taylor Swift fans mean business with Tortured Poets soap, Eras yarn, Kelce cookies
summary: Sparta Candle Co. has created soaps inspired by Taylor Swifts latest album, "The Tortured Poets Department." The "Tortured Poet" soap features notes of Earl Grey tea, bergamot, and lemon and comes in the shape of a cup of tea with a detachable saucer. Sewrella Yarn has also released a yarn collection inspired by Swifts Eras tour, with colors matching the different aesthetics of her past albums. Entrepreneur Emily Henegar of Cookie in the Kitchen creates intricate cookies incorporating details from Swifts work and life. Small businesses on Etsy are thriving by creating Swift-inspired products, responding quickly to her music, lyrics, and fashion choices. Etsy trend expert Dayna Isom Johnson notes a surge in searches for concert-inspired friendship bracelets and poetry-related items following Swifts songs and appearances. Law professor Jennifer Rothman suggests that Swifts open attitude towards fan creativity benefits her by fostering positive feelings and boosting her brand.

title: Idaho's biggest hospital says emergency flights for pregnant patients up sharply
summary:
In Idaho, the states largest hospital system, St. Lukes, has reported a surge in emergency flights for pregnant patients seeking abortions out of state following the implementation of the states strict abortion ban. However, Idaho Attorney General Raul Labrador has questioned these figures, suggesting that St. Lukes may be exaggerating to "make a political statement."

St. Lukes contends that the flights are necessary to protect patient health and prevent organ damage, while Labrador insists that the law protects doctors and allows abortions in cases where the mothers life is in jeopardy.

The Supreme Court is currently considering the case, with the U.S. government arguing that Idahos law conflicts with the federal mandate requiring hospitals to stabilize patients in emergencies. The Courts ruling on this matter is expected this summer.

Meanwhile, Idaho has experienced an exodus of reproductive health specialists due to the abortion ban, with a study indicating a 22% loss of obstetricians and gynecologists since its enactment.

title: Campus protests over Gaza could affect graduation; Steve Inkseep interviews Blinken
summary:
Across the United States, hundreds of students have been arrested during protests against Israels actions in Gaza. The protests began a week ago after police removed an encampment of demonstrators at Columbia University; however, the students quickly reestablished their encampment. Similar protests have since been organized at schools such as UT Austin and the City College of New York.

The Supreme Court heard arguments regarding whether former President Donald Trump should be granted immunity from prosecution for his actions after the 2020 election. Trumps lawyers assert that his attempts to stay in power were part of his official duties; however, the majority of the Court seemed skeptical of this argument.

New Yorks top court has overturned the 2020 felony sex crime conviction of Harvey Weinstein, ruling that he did not receive a fair trial. While a new trial has been ordered, Weinstein remains in prison due to a separate conviction from a California trial.

NPRs Steve Inskeep observed several changes in China during a recent visit, noting the increased presence of delivery drivers on electric motorbikes. Inskeep also spoke to U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken following a meeting between Blinken and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

NPRs "Pop Culture Happy Hour" recommends the film "Challengers," while NPRs Glen Weldon offers a review of Netflixs "Baby Reindeer." Amy Tans latest book, "The Backyard Bird Chronicles," is also highlighted, and St. Vincent discusses her new album, "All Born Screaming," on NPR.

title: Blinken tells China it's in their interest to stop helping Russia
summary: During his visit to Beijing, Secretary of State Antony Blinken met with Chinese leader Xi Jinping to discuss a range of issues, including Russias invasion of Ukraine. Blinken urged China to stop providing support to Russias defense industry, as it damages relations with European nations who view Russia as a threat. Chinas foreign ministry rejected this advice, claiming hypocrisy from the US for aiding Ukraine while complaining about Chinas trade with Russia. Despite tense relations, both Blinken and Xi agreed on the need for ongoing communication and potential areas of cooperation. Blinken emphasized the importance of restricting access to advanced technology that could be used against the US, while stating that economic decoupling is not the goal. The visit highlighted the contrasting public and private statements from Chinese officials, with public language expressing criticism but private conversations being more constructive. Blinken also addressed concerns over declining US reputation in China, particularly regarding support for Israels conflict with Hamas, and discussed the potential for China to play a constructive role in the Middle East by preventing escalation.

title: Trump's immunity arguments and the experiences of the justices who might support it
summary: The Supreme Courts oral arguments suggest a potential delay in a Trump trial for obstructing the 2020 election. Conservative justices, shaped by their experiences in Republican presidencies, expressed concerns about the potential misuse of criminal law against political opponents. Justice Kavanaugh questioned the application of conspiracy charges against presidential activities, while Justice Gorsuch expressed concerns about targeting political figures based on motives. Justice Alito suggested that criminal immunity for former presidents could foster democratic stability. Chief Justice Roberts, despite his background in the Reagan administration, remained less vocal on the matter. Notably, Justice Barrett, Trumps most recent appointee, challenged the immunity claims, questioning why presidents would be exempt from criminal prosecution compared to Supreme Court justices.

title: What to know about a possible Israeli military offensive in Rafah
summary:
Over 1 million displaced Palestinians in Gazas Rafah are facing the threat of an Israeli military offensive. Israel claims the offensive is necessary to eliminate Hamas and release hostages, but negotiations for a ceasefire have stalled. Multiple officials have expressed concern over the potential civilian death toll, and the US has urged Israel to consider "alternate ways" of addressing the Hamas military presence.

The Israeli military has called up two reserve brigades and erected new tent encampments near Rafah, indicating preparations for an attack. Aid groups and UN agencies fear a humanitarian crisis, as Rafah is the main exit point for wounded Palestinians and humanitarian aid.

Humanitarian organizations have contingency plans for evacuation but lack specific information from Israel. The United Nations reports that hundreds of bodies are still being recovered in Gaza City after an Israeli raid on Al-Shifa hospital. Despite the threat, some displaced Palestinians are considering fleeing to Egypt or returning to Gaza City, as Israeli airstrikes have killed over 230 civilians in Rafah since March 21.

title: Pro-Palestinian campus protesters face looming deadlines and risk of arrest
summary: Pro-Palestinian encampments and demonstrations have surged at college campuses nationwide, leading to multiple clashes between police and protesters and numerous arrests. Columbia University protesters remain in negotiations with officials despite a midnight Tuesday deadline to clear their encampment, with talks expected to continue past Friday morning. George Washington University protesters continued their demonstration despite a 7 p.m. deadline, resulting in the closure of University Yard. Emory University saw confrontations between protesters and law enforcement, resulting in 28 arrests, including faculty members. Protesters were also arrested at schools including The Ohio State University, the University of Minnesota, Indiana University, and Princeton University. The University of Southern California canceled its main commencement ceremony and valedictorians speech due to safety concerns.

title: More than 500 people have been arrested at pro-Palestinian protests at colleges
summary: Amidst ongoing pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses nationwide, over 500 arrests have been made. At Columbia University, more than 100 protesters were detained after police attempted to dismantle an encampment, while negotiations are ongoing. The University of Southern California experienced 93 arrests and canceled its commencement due to protests, including an assault charge. The University of Texas at Austin cleared protestors and charges were dropped for most of the 60 arrested. Emerson College apprehended over 100 protestors following the removal of an encampment. On Thursday, arrests were made at Princeton University, Emory University, The Ohio State University, and the University of Minnesota.

title: United Methodist Church begins reorganization over LGBTQ+ issues
summary: The United Methodist Churchs General Conference has voted to potentially lift the bans on LGBTQ+ clergy and same-sex weddings. A regionalization proposal would allow different geographic regions to create their own rules, enabling the U.S. to potentially end such bans while other regions make their own decisions. This move aims to address the disparity in sentiment towards LGBTQ+ issues among different parts of the church, particularly between the U.S. and Africa. The regionalization plan passed with 78% of the vote, but needs ratification by local annual conferences. Despite official bans, many local geographic conferences, especially in the U.S., have chosen not to enforce them, leading to departures from the denomination. The regionalization vote could make subsequent proposals to remove the bans globally less contentious.

title: A year later, Florida businesses say the state's immigration law dealt a huge blow.
summary: In Plant City, Florida, the immigration crackdown initiated by Governor Ron DeSantis has resulted in a shortage of farmworkers, causing significant losses for local businesses. Over 40% of farmworkers nationwide are estimated to be undocumented, and the fear of arrest under the new law has led many of them to leave Florida. The Florida Policy Institute estimates the law could cost the states economy $12.6 billion in the first year. Despite the availability of H-2A guest worker programs, farmers face high costs and bureaucratic hurdles that hinder their effectiveness. The labor shortage is also impacting non-agricultural industries, with businesses experiencing difficulties finding workers, particularly in roofing. The law has also created a climate of fear for undocumented workers and their families, leading many of them to consider moving out of Florida.

title: Alabama woman who says police assaulted her after calling 911 files federal lawsuit
summary: Twyla Stallworth, a Black woman from Alabama, filed a federal lawsuit against Andalusia City, its police department, and Officer Grant Barton for her unlawful arrest and illegal detention. The incident arose from a noise complaint Stallworth made, which prompted Barton to demand her identification. Stallworth refused, and Barton arrested her for failing to comply. The lawsuit alleges that Stallworth was assaulted, strip-searched, and jailed for 15 hours, despite not committing any crimes. Stallworth and her son, Jermari Marshall, are seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages. Andalusias mayor apologized for the incident and stated that Barton was disciplined, but the lawsuit does not specify the nature of the punishment. Stallworths attorney, Harry Daniels, condemned Bartons actions, highlighting the danger posed by officers who disregard citizens rights.

title: Former tabloid publisher details actions on behalf of Trump ahead of 2016 election
summary: In the ongoing hush-money trial against former President Trump, David Pecker, ex-publisher of the National Enquirer, testified that Keith Davidson approached the tabloid in 2016 with a story about Karen MacDougal, a model alleging an affair with Trump. Trump instructed Pecker to purchase and suppress the story, which American Media Inc. did at Cohens promise of reimbursement. Peckers testimony supports the prosecutions claim that Trump had direct knowledge of the hush-money payments. The trial also heard details of secret payments and buried stories, providing insight into Trumps methods of controlling information during his 2016 campaign. Peckers actions, motivated by Trumps gratitude, included a dinner at the White House where Trump inquired about MacDougal. Despite Trumps plea of not guilty to charges of falsifying business records, Peckers testimony suggests Trumps involvement in the payments.

title: Where can you call an artist on a lobster? Find out in the quiz
summary: This week marked Earth Day, an event often associated with corporate greenwashing and the misconception that individual actions can significantly reduce pollution. The concept of individual responsibility in reducing pollution was created by industries promoting single-use plastics. This topic is explored in depth in the Throughline podcasts Earth Day quiz, which challenges listeners with questions about the environmental impact of various products.

title: China's influence operations against the U.S. are bigger than TikTok
summary:
Amid national security concerns, a new law mandates the sale of the Chinese-owned TikTok app in the US. Lawmakers cite fears of China potentially accessing user data, conducting surveillance, and disseminating misinformation. While classified intelligence briefings have raised concerns about TikTok, no evidence has been publicly released.

Chinas efforts to manipulate Americans through social media have intensified, including attempts to influence elections, spread disinformation, and exacerbate existing divisions. While much attention has been given to Russian interference, Chinas efforts are also a growing threat.

TikTok has been utilized in Chinas influence operations, but not more than other platforms like Facebook. However, in Taiwan, China has aggressively used TikTok to undermine democracy, creating proxy accounts to disseminate official state narratives without disclosing their origins.

Despite efforts to sway Taiwanese voters, the pro-independence candidate opposed by China won re-election, indicating that these influence operations have not had a significant impact.

title: Ukraine pulls U.S.-provided Abrams tanks from the front lines over drone threats
summary: Due to Russian drone warfare, Ukraine has temporarily suspended the use of US-provided Abrams M1A1 tanks, as they have become highly vulnerable to detection and attack. The tanks have faced difficulties operating without being quickly located and targeted by Russian drones. Despite the US providing 31 Abrams tanks in January 2023, five have been lost to Russian attacks. The battlefield has shifted, making it challenging to protect the tanks from detection and strikes. The US and Ukraine are collaborating to modify tactics to enhance the effectiveness of the tanks in the current drone-heavy environment. While the tanks remain significant, the US is emphasizing counter-drone capabilities, air defenses, and alternative vehicles in its recent military aid packages. Ukraine has not yet adopted combined arms warfare tactics, which could increase the effectiveness of the Abrams tanks.

title: 17 states challenge federal rules entitling workers to accommodations for abortion
summary: Republican attorneys general from 17 states have filed a lawsuit challenging new federal regulations that entitle workers to time off and other accommodations for abortions. The lawsuit alleges that the rules, finalized on Monday by the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), exceed the scope of the 2022 Pregnant Workers Fairness Act, which passed with bipartisan support. The regulations, which go into effect on June 18th, allow workers to seek time off to obtain and recover from an abortion. The lawsuit argues that the regulations force employers to accommodate abortions, even if they are illegal under state law. The EEOC maintains that the regulations only provide for time off, which does not have to be paid. The lawsuit was led by Tennessee and Arkansas, with Alabama, Florida, and 12 other states joining.

title: Why experts say inflation is relatively low but voters feel differently
summary: Purdue Universitys report indicates that a majority of consumers anticipate continued food price increases, potentially impacting voter sentiment. Despite heightened consumer perception of inflation, data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows a lower 2.2% increase in food prices over the past year. The report also reveals a political divide in perceived inflation, with Republicans reporting higher rates than Democrats. Consumers may overestimate price changes due to a broader time frame than the CPIs one-month comparison. The report suggests that rising food prices could negatively impact election outcomes, although specific drivers of inflation have diminished. While labor costs remain a lingering factor, the report does not anticipate a return to previous levels of food price inflation.

title: Kim Kardashian visits the White House to highlight criminal justice reform
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris met with reality TV star Kim Kardashian to discuss criminal justice reform. The meeting focused on a new rule by the Small Business Administration that eases loan restrictions for individuals with criminal records. Harris emphasized the importance of second chances and resources for ex-offenders. President Biden has recently granted clemency to 11 individuals for non-violent drug offenses and commuted the sentences of five others. Bidens reforms aim to address disproportionate sentencing and attract young and minority voters, who advocate for marijuana reform. Kardashians advocacy played a role in elevating the issue during the previous administration.

title: Haiti's Prime Minister Ariel Henry has resigned as a transitional council takes over
summary: Ariel Henry, Haitis de facto prime minister, has resigned and appointed Finance Minister Michel Patrick Boisvert as interim prime minister. A nine-person transitional council, including seven voting members, has been sworn in to select Haitis new prime minister and cabinet. The councils swearing-in ceremony occurred amidst gunfire, as gangs have vowed to topple the government. Gangs control most of the capital, cutting it off from the outside world and displacing over 90,000 people. Former Prime Minister Henry is unable to return to Haiti from Los Angeles due to gang-led violence. The transitional council is tasked with paving the way for an international peacekeeping force.

title: Venice tests a 5-euro fee for day-trippers as the city grapples with overtourism
summary: Venice has introduced a pilot program requiring day-trippers to pay a €5 entry fee between 8:30 a.m. and 4 p.m. on specific dates through July to reduce overtourism and improve livability for residents. The measure includes separate entrances for tourists and residents, with on-site stewards guiding visitors through the QR code payment process. Despite protests, the program aims to track arrivals more accurately and monitor crowd levels. Critics argue that the fee is ineffective and that the city should focus on increasing the resident population and services to address tourisms negative impact. Venice officials have recorded approximately 10,000 paid day-tripper arrivals on the first day, with over 70,000 others downloading QR codes for exemptions.

title: After two Boeing 737 Max crashes, families are still seeking answers from DOJ
summary: Families of victims killed in two 737 Max jet crashes in 2018 and 2019 met with Justice Department prosecutors and expressed frustration over the lack of criminal prosecution against Boeing. Despite the company reaching a $2.5 billion settlement with the department, victims relatives believe Boeing avoided criminal charges and are urging prosecutors to hold the company accountable. Although Boeing has paid billions in settlements, the families view the Justice Departments agreement with the company as a betrayal. The families frustration was compounded by a recent incident where a door plug panel blew out of a 737 Max jet, prompting a Justice Department investigation. Prosecutors have yet to provide substantial answers to the families questions, leaving them doubting their concerns are being taken seriously. The Justice Department could extend Boeings probation deal or drop the criminal case altogether within the next two months.

title: Some 300 musicians, from Diplo to Nile Rodgers, lobby Congress for ticketing reform
summary: Over 280 musicians, including Billie Eilish, Dave Matthews, and Diplo, have signed a letter urging senators to reform the concert ticketing system. They argue that predatory resellers inflate ticket prices and deprive fans of affordable access. The artists support the Fans First Act, which aims to increase transparency, protect consumers, and deter illegal activities in the ticketing industry. Senator Amy Klobuchar, a co-sponsor of the bill, expressed support for its passage. The letters release comes amidst increased scrutiny of Ticketmaster and Live Nation, following the chaotic sale of Taylor Swift tour tickets and allegations of anti-competitive practices. Lawmakers have introduced multiple bills to address ticketing concerns, and the Justice Department is reportedly investigating Live Nation.

title: Harvey Weinstein's 2020 sex crimes conviction in New York overturned
summary: The New York State Court of Appeals overturned Harvey Weinsteins 2020 felony sex crime conviction due to the admission of testimony from women not involved in the case, violating his rights to a fair trial. The court ruled that the testimony from these "Molineux witnesses" unfairly bolstered the credibility of the complainants by emphasizing Weinsteins past behavior. Critics argue that the subjective application of the "Molineux Rule" can lead to challenges to verdicts. The Manhattan district attorneys office intends to retry the case, while Weinstein currently faces a 16-year sentence from a separate Los Angeles conviction. As of now, he is being held in the Mohawk Correctional Facility in upstate New York.

title: An American hostage is seen alive for the first time since Oct. 7 in a Hamas video
summary: Hamas has released a video showing Hersh Goldberg-Polin, an Israeli-American hostage kidnapped in Gaza in October 2023. The video marks the first time Hamas has released a video of one of the five Americans it holds captive. Goldberg-Polin, 24, appears in the video with a healed stump where his left forearm was amputated. He criticizes Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu and claims Israeli airstrikes have killed other hostages. The video has sparked protests in Israel, with Goldberg-Polins parents urging negotiators to reach a cease-fire to reunite families and end suffering. President Biden and leaders of 17 other countries have issued a joint statement calling on Hamas to agree to a cease-fire deal that would include the release of the hostages.

title: How's your city attracting people downtown these days? NPR wants to hear from you
summary: Many downtowns are facing reduced activity due to hybrid work and other post-pandemic lifestyle changes. In response, cities are implementing various initiatives to revitalize these areas. These efforts include hosting special events, offering business incentives, and increasing housing options near office buildings. NPR is seeking submissions from individuals about what attracts them to downtowns and ideas for their revitalization. Submissions will be subject to NPRs Terms of Use and Privacy Policy, which notes that journalistic activities and freedom of expression may have exemptions that override certain privacy rights.
